body:
While there is a convenience method for `List<Header>`, it actually just gets wrapped in a `Provider<List<Header>>` which is called for every request. If you pass one of these providers instead, you'll be able to change what it returns at any point.

This is useful if, say, you want to include the users last known location in a request or maybe authentication information for the current logged in user.

It should also be noted that there currently isn't a way to change the headers based on which request method is being called (short of using separate `RestAdapter`s). We haven't seen a use case where this has been required so for now it's being omitted.

What if the currently logged in user logs out and logs in as a different user?

The Drupal API I'm interfacing with requires a cookie header to authenticate each request. If a user changes their credentials, I need to change the cookie value, which from what I've seen requires a new RestAdapter to be built with the Builder. I was trying to avoid that since the RestAdapter is a singleton provided by Dagger, and I couldn't figure out how to re instantiate it.

Now that I think of it, I probably should have asked this in the Dagger repo.

issue.title: Switch headers to come from an interface implementation.

repository.name: retrofit
repository.description: A type-safe HTTP client for Android and the JVM

issue.body:
This makes it much more easy to provide dynamic headers. Rather than dealing with a Provider, you can now have a concrete class implement this interface.

Closes #146.

body:
Currently there isn't a way to change the headers based on which request method is being called. 
I have a use case where it would make sense to have this feature:
I have to specify a signature of the request method in an header, and this signature depends on a SHA256 of a string which is a composition of accessKey, methodName, uri, timestamp and user_agent. 

wdyt @JakeWharton ?
I'm not sure how this would be supported. Would you want a interface name and method name passed to the `Headers`?

@JakeWharton also we could work on something like Filter [1](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/jre/api/net/httpserver/spec/com/sun/net/httpserver/Filter.html) to pre-process the httpRequest and manipulate it, where a Filter will be passed as an annotation to the API interface.

Retrofit's `Request` is immutable by design, though.

What about a `@Header` annotation which work like `@Name` for method arguments?
I think @Header will be useful, but not sure it will cover my scenario as I need to inject some calculated value for some header like signature. wdyt?

I think the simplest thing is to implement custom headers as a custom HTTP client. For the most part headers are a property of the HTTP client anyway. That also makes for a natural place to deal with cookies and such.
(... which is to say, we don't need any code changes. If you want custom headers, just customize your HTTP client implementation.)
Thanks @swankjesse I've already implemented that way, just trying to think about a different support.
